body.content: I think now it's at a point where as a challenge to myself I want to see if I can do it for 365 days it's been also just a good way to train my creative and ideation muscles cuz if you force yourself to have to come up with something every day it keeps you pretty sharp welcome to Dive Club my name is rid and this is where we go deep with the best designers so that you can learn from their journey and apply it to your own career if you've opened Twitter at all in the last year then you're definitely familiar with saurin Iverson's satirical designs like uber HotBox or maybe even the iMessage typing indicator so I wanted to talk to him to learn more about his creative process but also to identify what designers can learn from his journey like strategies for staying consistent how to jump start your Network online and how saurin has refined his product sense while designing at Cash app but first I wanted to get a behind the scenes to learn more about what it was like collaborating with dual lingo I had been posting stuff pretty regularly for I want to say four or five months and I had had a lot of startups that had reached out about doing collab posts or sponsored posts and the interesting thing about my content is the level of reaction and the funniness is contingent on your understanding with the underlying platform so if you have a niche crypto startup that you're making satirical designs of it's going to be be a head scratcher for most people on the timeline but dual lingo reached out first I thought like there's no way this is legit like this this kid be people that work at duelingo and then they did so that was really exciting I spoke with them a little bit it's an interesting project because at the end of the day it's really just a sponsored post but you're also trying to figure out how to price ideation as a service and so we ended up landing on basically creating more ideas then would end up being publicly posted I will never forget this it was the only client that I've ever shown work to and they liked the work but they asked in the second round could this be more unhinged um not a normal thing that you ask for but I think dual Ino it's interesting you look at their their Tik Tok presence their Instagram presence they are pretty out there they've got the bird twerking in public stuff like that so we ended up landing on a few different concepts one of which was the Dual lingo option to serve and translate divorce papers and we had scheduled that to be posted on a different date and then what ended up happening was Trudeau and his partner announced their separation and so dualingo capitalized on that I I think I had sent them that image like a couple days before and it just blew up so that was really it was really fun seeing the the payoff there both in terms of of Engagement for them and then I was really nervous when I posted it because I'm very careful about doing sponsored content in general and I posted that and disclosed that it was and people were overall very positive about the collaboration so it was a really fun engagement and there are many other Concepts that are in the graveyard from that project that may never see the light of day which is a bit sad but part of the process can you go a little bit deeper on what that process looks like like specifically the ideation part because I would imagine you probably felt a little bit more pressure than normal because you're not just doing it for yourself it's all of a sudden part of this agreement where you're expected to perform and you want to perform well so like how did you tackle that ideation process for dualingo yeah I think because I do this every day and I give myself a little bit more leeway the lpness test is usually does it at least make make me kind of breathe through my nose laugh when I look at it I think with the Dual lingo stuff I actually at First had a little freak out I'm like oh man this like really has to be funny and then I saw someone asked about like how do you overcome creative block and this might not be a very popular answer but I usually just brute force it and time constraints and really not allowing yourself to spiral on stuff is the the most effective way for me and then just making something even though the first version is probably going to be bad so with the dual lingo stuff I had had a couple like very loose ideas of what to do but they were pretty tame and so I made those and then I started using the app more regularly and then as I used the app more it became more clear like patterns that could be subverted like for example the the loader screen right like the bird pops up and you have his eyes and I was like what if he was high and so like you take like the eyes and make them look kind of red um and then also a big unlock was early on a lot of what I did was combining kind of just two apps and like mashing them together really what you're doing is two ecosystems are colliding two product ecosystems and I had the idea of du lingo bird or Duo being a sentient entity that like escapes the app and then once like IOS as a whole became Duo's playground I think there were a lot more opportunities for it to do really interesting things but I think back to the original like what did that process look like it was really forcing myself to just get into the work being okay with the first couple rounds to myself and generally not being great the phrase like got to crack a couple eggs to make an omelette is very real so it's easy to spend time thinking about and worrying about the work and I found that instead of letting myself get stuck there just doing it and getting the bad stuff out out of my system on paper is often very helpful in overcoming that initial block and getting to the point where the work is good so one of my favorite post that you've done is the Uber HotBox and I went back to look at it and I noticed that you had to clarify that it was in fact satire almost two weeks after posting which is pretty unlike you so is there a story there if I post something and it goes viral within my own network it will get a lot of Engagement but there are moments where I post something and it gets picked up by a presence on the internet with a really large footprint with an audience that doesn't understand me at all it was either Wall Street bets or grape juice boys found that post and then they just cropped all of the Tweet details out of it and just made it it looked like it was the UI for Uber right so they posted that and then it got posted on redit and then it got posted all over Twitter so my friend sent me an article and it was a fact check notice from Reuters so said if you Google Uber Hot Box option it says no Uber is not offering a hot box option which I try to be overly unhinged with the sub copy so I think it says writers that are down with the devil's lce or something like that which like no one would ever say that but I had a moment of panic where I was like am I going to get a cease and desist from Uber like what's going to happen and I talked I talked with a friend of mine who's a lawyer and he was like it's satire you're it's a protected thing under this version of so I was less worried then but it also wasn't super clear that it was satire so I was like if I denote that it's satire so then I did and then people were like of course this is satire I'm like I know you know a lot of people don't know and still to this day when I post on X Twitter whatever when I post there people know that it's satire when I post on threads most people don't know that it's satire so the Tinder bald prediction people thought that was real and people got really mad so it's interesting when you're deep in a discipline you make a lot of assumptions about what people know and don't know I think same is true of design right it's very easy to not put yourself in the shoes of the customer when you're building something and jump to a lot of conclusions that wouldn't necessarily be true I think it's obvious that like not everyone listening to this episode episode is going to go viral and build this massive audience but there definitely is an uptick for designers that I've noticed around just like this desire to start building distribution for their ideas and getting noticed on social so can we reverse engineer your success a little bit what do you think you're doing at a higher level that other designers can look at and try to emulate I think there are a few things I think one is is I combined two distinct genres of content in a novel way a semi Noel way I think you a long time ago you would see very like lowf UI memes but I as far as I know was the first person to really do that in a humorous context on a consistent basis doing that where you kind of identify either a topic and a sub Niche or two genres I you just design and comedy and then you mix those in a novel way you're kind of refusing to play the game that everyone is playing whether that's being a thought leader or like posting visual work and there's nothing wrong with either of those things but I think that was a large part of My Success I believe if I had to kind of break it down into kind of trying to distill advice to someone I think being consistent is very difficult and I see a lot of people that will decide that they want to build something or increase their distribution and they'll do it for a couple weeks maybe but it really takes consistent effort for months to see kind of outsized returns and it's it's hard to have that self-discipline especially with designers perfectionism right having everything need to be absolutely perfect I've posted the stuff with typos I've posted stuff with incorrect captions I I've sent out emails to 5,000 people that had the wrong cont content in it it's like you're going to make mistakes and I think in my case actually when there are typos I've realized people will just correct them I'm like you're I think this is just for engagement right and then also some people aren't even at the point where they feel like they would be able to grow their own audience right because they're like I have no audience and I think the way to start from there is to build a community of people that will support you the lowest possible version of this is the the people that are just going to tell you to like reply to people's stuff and it's like people are not rob thoughts like you're going to meet these people in person maybe one day at a conference so I think strategically building relationships and providing value to those people I look at like Alex uh who I think he's a designer at gather now but he he did that framer tool I can't remember what it's called the top of my head overrides right he started I don't think he had more than 100 followers at the beginning of the year but he's been really consistent he has provided a ton of value and I think he's done a really good job of building relationships with designers that are have a larger distribution set than him and I think also the idea of having a large following does not necessarily correlate to higher value so if you're building distribution If I Could Turn Back Time thinking about who you want to distribute to should directly influence the type of content that you want to create right so if you're wanting to distribute to other designers the content would look very different than if you want to gain distribution to businesses that need design help and that would look very different than building an audience of people that just like comedy right so I think being thoughtful about your audience being consistent and ideally trying to find a way to change the game that is being played right I think there are only so many thought leaders that can thought lead and I think some people differentiate themselves through visual design skills and then I don't know I think Life's too short to try to like do someone else's thing I think just like being you and bringing whatever unique skill sets and life experiences you have to the table is is a really good way to do it I like this idea of kind of evaluating what you think your unique intersection of skills and interests are and trying to be the best at that intersection Point rather than like the best visual designer in a sea of really really talented visual designers I also think you do hear this build relationships phrase pretty frequently and sometimes it's like okay yeah I need to go out and build relationships and then you wake up on Monday morning and it's like okay now what does this actually look like you know so can we drill into that a little bit more like as someone that is listening that maybe has like 100 followers on Twitter that just really wants to get more plugged in and connect with people what are some strategies that you would consider using to kind of jump start that initial Network yeah so I think one thing that I see a lot of people that are starting their career outd doing is they don't have a ton to quote unquote give but what ends up happening is it becomes a lot of kind of transactional relationships it's like hey can you review my portfolio hey can you can you Mentor me there's nothing there's nothing wrong with that and I I understand especially for people entering the market it's a tough market right now but I think looking at someone like Alex cuz I think I started interacting with him when he only had like a couple thousand or like a thousand followers and it was largely because he was doing really interesting work and was engaging publicly with people and then I think at some point we started dming I don't know if he dm' me or I dm' him but I look at the people that do DM me that I'm like oh this is worth responding to the bar is actually really low I think people that go out of their way to find or curate interesting things or if they have really thoughtful questions I think there are a lot of people who are very smart and articulate and have good ideas but I think a lot of people like that tend to overthink things and that can often result in an aversion to for lack of a better world like vomiting your thoughts onto the timeline cuz like I I I I think like I used to be like this too it's like I was so just like scared of like posting anything I think once I stopped overthinking it it was a really helpful way for me to know put myself out there cuz that was a large part of the unlock for me is realizing like the person that's thinking most about the thing that you're doing is definitely you so back to the original question tactical strategies I would say are if there's someone that you look up to and admire and you have something that you can bring to the conversation like you don't need to necessarily help them but like maybe if you found something that you think would be thought-provoking share that with them if you have a really thoughtful question send that to them I think those are the types of things that kind of can begin relationships was there a point in your journey where you made the shift from like hey wouldn't this be funny and kind of throwing it out there to okay there's something here I actually do see the potential to invest in audience growth long term and how has that switch evolved your process and how you think about the way you put your work out there and the way that you invest in this growth and network initially the early early Concepts were me making fun of Spotify wrapped and seeing like what would happen if you subverted that or extracted that pattern and put it into other products and those were really quick one-offs and they were fun and it was a nice kind of change of pace from serious work and then in pretty quick succession chat GPT came out and so I started kind of thinking about what would happen if you extracted chat GPT and put it into different product surfaces and at that moment I realized oh you can really take two seemingly unrelated products and you can smash them together right so I started doing that more and more and I just committed to myself to do it daily if I could and then after a couple weeks I just thought I'm going to see how long I could run this thing and I I think now it's at a point where as a challenge to myself I want to see if I can do it for 365 days it's been also just a good way to train my creative and ideation muscles cuz if you force yourself to have to come up with something every day it keeps you pretty sharp you mentioned 365 days you're like approaching that number I think you're right around like 350 now 330 is 330 okay we'll call it 330 when you look at this journey these last 330 plus days like what are some of the mechanisms that you've put in place to help yourself be consistent because I think a lot of designers hear about the value of consistency but it is really hard to do so what do you think people can learn from your journey and how you've been able to stay consistent if you tell yourself you're going to do something hold yourself accountable to do it I've had some pretty gnarly weeks with this like I'm in a band and we were on tour and I was designing Concepts from the car at 3: in the morning to make sure that I like hit the 7: a.m. deadline also if you're doing a lot of things the consistency actually be becomes easier over time so when I started this process I had no backlog of content right I had nothing to pull off of I was kind of trying to Cobble together Concepts every day and about 2 or 3 months in I realized that I had really crude visual systems that I could basically use to build new Concepts right so then it went from oh I need to rebuild linkedin's entire feed to oh I need to go find that concept and that concept and like take these things and swap out these images and then add an illustration here as you train the muscle it become you become more efficient and you'll learn where you find snags in the process and so I think for me at least the first month was really fun and energizing and then month two and three was still a lot of work so it started to feel like a slog and then now I've gotten to the point where I kind I have the Rhythm I I know what I'm doing and it's become something that's just become a part of my my daily routine right I think it takes like 30 some days or some I don't know if this is true it takes 30 something days to build a habit I think anyone that wants to be consistent whether it's making sure you do spend time learning a new skill within design every day whether it's making sure that you post on social every day whether it's like working out every day like it's just getting out and doing it something that I think most people might not realize is that you're not just making these mockups and then dumping them on Twitter with a little oneliner but you're actually sending them out in a newsletter where you have like a couple paragraphs where you're writing about the concept and what inspired it and how you approached it and that's a big part of what this consistency looks like as well and then I was reading something that you wrote a couple years ago where you talked about the advice that you would give your younger self is to start wri writing can you talk about why and what that's unlocked in your own career in University typically there's a lot of writing assignments and it can feel like just writing for writing's sake I look at the amount of people that I interact with on the internet and the ability to thoughtfully articulate yourself while having a unique tone of voice is an art form and it really benefits those people and then on the other side when you're working with people particularly in a remote context you really need to be able to write well similar to anything creative the more you do it the easier it becomes and the more it helps you develop your own tone of voice your own style I think also it becomes a permanent artifact of your thinking right and you can always revise your thinking later but I think they're interesting milestones and things to look back on it's like oh I really said that like two years ago I think documenting those things even if you never share them publicly it's just a good way to process what's happening in your head I was researching this episode just trying to learn a little bit more about you and it's interesting to note like you were co-founder of a payments product and then you have a minor in business and back in 2021 your favorite podcast was the Bloomberg Masters in Business podcast so you obvious have like a little bit of business interest there and now you have this large platform form you've done the book you already have the plans for the second book when you kind of look into the future a bit further like what are some of the other ways that you're experimenting or thinking about how to create new opportunities for yourself I think in the short term I'll be working on another book I think looking farther than that I want to make sure that if I do create something that I charge money for it has a really high level of utility and all also has my kind of unique spin on it I I don't want to fall into a world where I'm you know making some sort of like course or framework that's super practical and doesn't have like my thumb print on it and I'm still trying to figure out what exactly that means in practice uh I've been experimenting a little bit with actually just building applications so I had like a walking Battle Royale app where there was a leaderboard and the leaderboard would reset every day I think that was a really good way to learn in public public ultimately I realized that to get that thing to a level where I'd be proud of it and would want to ship it I'm going to need to work with an actual Dev partner unless I want to scrap everything and just work on that all the time which is not what I want to do but yeah I think there are some like digital products that I'm looking at there are mobile applications that I'm looking at and then I also think it would be really fun if I had time and bandwidth which we'll see I want to make unhinged physical products so I had the idea for like a calendar where you literally have to touch grass every day or like the hamster water bottle feeders but it's like for your desk and it mounts like right up here and then there's like the metal rod there so you can just like use that to get water I I I like I like the idea of what I've done digitally like spilling over into the the physical world there's a lot more Logistics that go into that with manufacturers but even as one-offs I think that could be really fun you mentioned the like thumb print print of sain I think a lot of people know you as like the satirical design guy and like maybe that you also work at Cash app or something like that but what else do you want people to know about sain Iverson and who you are you think about it in spheres right so anyone it's like oh he's the guy that makes weird UI and then I think you go a layer deeper and people are like oh that's s like he works at Cash app he's in this band he does this stuff and then I think there's a layer deeper where people know me more personally it's just layers of intimacy right and so I obviously can control what I do and I've decided that I'm okay with the general public knowing me for one thing but I think people that know me on a deeper level will see what it's like to work with me as an actual designer and I think the way that I've decided to show my work to the world demonstrates that I have one a sense of humor but I think there's also a a signal that there's a pretty deep understanding of product thinking and that often leads to people reaching out about serious stuff right I don't think they're mutually exclusive and I think something that I had a hard time with for a long time is that the internet rewards myopic Behavior so the more consistent in the type of content that you create the more likely that you will gain distribution the thing that I did not realize until this year here is that even if you have significant distribution for a certain thing there will be a small subset of that distribution set that is more interested in you as a person and I think those relationships are the ones that are more interesting to obviously for me to invest in and I think people make the mistake of kind of staking their entire selfworth on their internet reputation I think I've been in that head space before and I know how bad it is for you and so I just kind of hold it Loosely I think you know the people who are close to me know who I am and the people that have worked with me know what it's like to work with me and then there's the world that knows me for funny stuff and I think it's okay to have those be separate things you mentioned the product thinking part which it definitely does stand out in your designs and also you know I've seen many many comments people being like wow you know like this should totally be a real thing and you talked about how you've kind of grown a little bit just by exposure to all of these apps on a consistent basis over the last year but maybe even before 2023 what are some of the ways that you think you've been able to grow as a product thinker and kind of grow the muscle of what people would refer to as like product sense I think with product there are a few tactical things which is one like Lenny's newsletter has infinite resources I think two there is inspired by Marty Kagan which is a really great book I read that before I started at Square I think there are kind of two things that I have learned for my time working with product at cach a square I learned a lot about using design as a way to paint a picture of the future and help align people towards that so while you're still doing work on whatever your quarterly objectives are or the Sprint that you're currently working on you need to do that work and you need to do it well but then I think also really using PM as a thought partner and then showing them here's what our product could look like in a year or two years or half a year I think showing people that you're thinking strategically about what the product can look like in the future and mapping that back to how it will help the business and how it will help the customer I think will go a long way in being able to kind of insert your influence with a product partner and then I think also I've never had a PM be upset by trying to take work off their plate right so you can insert yourself into the process of product requirements document creation product strategy and like really as a product designer that is part of what you should be doing and I think those are muscles that I'm still training right but I think all of those things have been have played a role and then also having my own know things you just have to learn because you're everything's kind of on fire all the time and you just need to you need to make sure it works and you're you have something that customers are using and you need to keep it alive in the short term and you need to figure out kind of like what you're building towards when you look into 2024 are there other muscles that you really want to focus on training or ways that you're hoping to grow as a designer I think I'm toying with two things one is code the second is getting better at organizing myself and systems the initial figma file that I was using for the ideas was horrifying it's actually pretty organized now but I think normally like my actual design files are pretty organized I'm talking more about like Building Systems for organizing communication organizing how I post stuff systematizing inquiries for paid collaborations and also Outsourcing I think I have historically been very averse to kind of handing over the keys to anyone and I'm realizing that that is getting in my way at this point and so as opportunities to Outsource arise in 2024 I'm going to try to more thoughtfully pursue that rather than trying to put more stuff on my plate can you talk about the code piece a little bit more you've mentioned that a couple times now what's the underlying motivation that makes you want to invest in something like that especially when you have like a million other things on your plate and then maybe can you talk a little bit about like how you approach learning learning something like that I'm going to start very zoomed out and then zoom in I think if you look at product design as a discipline 13 15 years ago it was people putting together websites in like Photoshop and Flash right and then it it became there was this influx of capital in the early 2010s and tech companies were able to pay enough money that they were able to extract a lot of people from creative agencies and then they were building a lot of the early stage products they're also product designers that that came in at that point but I think the broader industry there was still like ux and UI as these kind of discrete disciplines and then 2010 to like 2015 those disciplines really started to converge and then 20 yeah 2015 to 2020 was really really the idea of product designer markets are efficient and they're going to find the most cost-effective way to do something and I think the kind of Holy Grail of that for design is from idea into production code right and so if you look at most mobile applications that are on iOS they're using some sort of Swift or Swift UI framework and it's never been easier for a designer to pick those things up and the tools are really collapsing all the different parts of that process into one process and so understanding how to talk to computers I think will be a requirement not a nice to have in the relatively near future and when I say talk to computers I I mean like code and build things that can be shipped right uh that that to say I think large companies have such complex engineering needs that it would be ignorant to think that designers could really do it all I think the idea of like design technologist as someone that is able to prototype demos that can be distributed to a team used to used with user testing I think a lot of those things are already happening and will continue to happen because it's way more cost effective so that was a large part of what spurred the learning also I have all these kind of ideas but I haven't been able to really like bring them to life other than prototyping and that was not being able to like fully close that Loop was really frustrating so I had a couple times tried to do the like hacking with Swift like 100 day project thing and I think those tutorials are great but the way that I realize that I learn things is I like build a thing and it's not great and I like look at it and I take it apart and I build it again it's kind of like playing with Legos but code I was initially so focused on kind of like getting it right the first time that I just wouldn't get it at all and so I allowed myself to do things in a very hacky way I built I remember like I the first thing I did was like a very basic like step tracker and I was like who this is sick I can like track my steps and then I like built another function into it that had like distance and calories and then I just started adding stuff and it's like very very messy and then after doing that even for a couple weeks I go back and look at the initial code implementation I was like what was I doing right different people learn in different ways there are some people that can literally just read a book and then they can internalize that information and then they can go do it I wish I could do that I can't but I think a lot of people do learn through like play I think showing that that was something I was doing in public was one a good way to like hold myself accountable and two a good way to show that like anyone can learn anything at any time and I think it's worth people sharing the early artifacts of that process to show that different people just learn things in different ways I think um people try some people not all people but some people try to really like showcase their their skills and their creative muscles and people don't want to you know show any of the like messy behind the scenes and I think showing some of the the mess behind the scenes cuz I realized in meeting a lot of people that I looked up to over the last few years that everyone's just trying to figure it out and so I think kind of like communicating that through the like learning in public has been um really fun for me and and hopefully helpful for a few people out there it's interesting how well it connects back to what we were talking about in terms of like audience growth strategies too because it's compelling content like I love following along with people's learning Journeys it's just a scary thing to share and so like if you can get over that hump it's actually a really really great way to start putting yourself out there and becoming like this magnet for people who are interested in the same things and and think like you do a metaphor that I recently started using that has been really helpful is you are like a billboard on the internet Highway this actually has a lot of things so like one the more consistent you are the more likely people are to recognize you and like engage with you two some people will really like will really like what's on the billboard and some people really won't and at the end of the day like that's just the nature of Being Human and being online it's also not you like it's it's a portrayal of like a part of you but like you are more than whatever you put online and so I think I do think learning in public is a really good strategy and I think I understand the fear of like looking stupid but I think I don't remember who said this that they said something around like the willingness to look stupid stupid is actually a pretty admirable thing I would cave that with saying in the right context it's good obviously there are like certain moments where you definitely don't want to look stupid but I think there's just a level of humility uh that comes with that and just really being willing to to mess up and and learn from those things it's good I love that metaphor we've covered a ton of ground is there anything that I haven't asked or anything else that you really want listeners to come away with from this conversation I think wrapping it up I would say consistency and self-discipline are muscles that you train over time and if you do invest in training them it'll really pay you dividends in the long run and two don't try to be something you're not I think you see a lot of people that are successful for x or y or Z online and it's easy to try and like copy them and I think actually copying people is a great way to start and to learn so I've seen a lot of people do stuff similar to what I'm doing and it's great I love when people do that I think it's a good way to kind of rip the Band-Aid off on getting comfortable making stuff and I think through that you often find what your unique angle is and then I think also with meeting new people and networking like one if there are events near you like go to them and even though it's scary like go say hi to that person and then online right like if there's someone that you really look up to tell them that ask them a question start a conversation even with people with large followings I think the bar is is pretty low and and sending a thoughtful note or a well-written email um can really go a long way in terms of building a relationship so yeah thanks for having me yeah awesome thank you so much s and like not just for taking the time to you know share a little bit more about how you think and who you are but also just for making our social feeds a little bit more entertaining every day we appreciate you happy to be of service
body.description:
If you‚Äôve opened Twitter in the last year then you‚Äôre definitely familiar with Soren Iverson‚Äôs satirical designs like Uber Hotbox and the iMessage typing indicator. In this episode we get an inside look at his process and lessons he‚Äôs learned throughout his career:

- How he overcomes creative blocks
- Strategies for being consistent
- What it was like collaborating with Duolingo
- How to jumpstart your network online
- Tactics for growing your product sense
- Why Soren is learning to code

Dive is where the best designers never stop learning ü§ø

üåê dive.club
üê¶ twitter.com/joindiveclub

Now you can join advanced courses taught by the top designers to help you take a huge leap forward in your career üí™

00:00 Introduction
2:25 Soren's creative process
5:05 Uber Hot Box story
7:25 Strategies for audience building for designers
11:50 How to jumpstart your network online
16:33 How Soren has stayed consistent
18:58 The importance of writing
20:37 Looking into the future
22:55 Getting to know Soren
25:20 Growing your product sense
27:40 Soren's growth areas for 2024
28:41 Why Soren is learning to code
33:12 You are a billboard on the internet highway

#productdesign #podcast #uiux
body.title: Soren Iverson - Training your creative muscles (Dive Club Ep. 29)
